item.title: 1949 Communist Takeover
item.description:
#history #history
#history
Tags: #history
Date of writing: 2025-05-05

In 1949, after the CCP won the Chinese Civil War following World War II, they were able to take over China and under the leadership of totalitarian leaders become an industrial superpower. In the Cold War, they played a crucial role in Communism in East Asia, both hindering and helping the U.S.S.R.

Overall sucks to determine economic success or failure, good for everything else!

What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (B)
Mao Zedong's charisma was enough to pull most of the nation to his side
--> as a leader, he was able to incite a massive revolution and contribute to the
How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (A)
Takeover shows the power of peasants (e.g common people) to contribute to political change
Probably the single largest event that shows how common people can contribute to political changes
What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (F)
This evidence just sucks, the other specific events and topics such as Land Reform were better.

item.title: 1953-1957 First 5-year plan
item.description:
#history
Tags: #history
Date of writing: 2025-05-05

The first 5-year plan succeeded to help trigger industrialization in China, unlike it's successor the 1958-1962 Great Leap Forward. This was achieved by Nationalization (which was only really completed in 1955-1956), a focus on heavy industry, and sacrifices by the people of China - the standard of living was raised very little, with strict rationing that guaranteed everyone enough food to live. The entire economy was governed by a bureaucratic system run from Beijing.
In the end, iron and steel production tripled, the output of coal increased from 65 million-130 million tons, and construction of dams/power plants began.

Overall: (A) really good piece of evidence for EQ 1 and 3 and enough to work on EQ 2

What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (A)
This shows us how the CCP was extremely powerful
With good administration, Mao was able to push China and start modernization extremely quickly.
The entire economy was run from Beijing, which shows how political leaders can have extreme power - to have the entire economy of a country under their direct control
Nationalization shows us how governments are able to seize and take resources from the populace, which could be dangerous and shows negative change, but could also be positive change.
How did people contribute to political changes in their country?
The success of the 5-year plan depended a lot on the workers
While they were forced to obey, it shows us how having a large population was extremely helpful to China's expansion
What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (S)
The 5-year plan helps to show how Nationalization was able to be successful, and was a major contributing factor to economic success.
The focus on heavy industry helped China become a superpower and showed the poewr

item.title: Taiwan Martial Law
item.description:
#history
Tags: #history
Date of writing: 2025-05-05

Martial law was enacted in Taiwan after the KMT arrival in order for the KMT to remain control, also known as the "White Terror", it was the second longest period of martial law in global history (second to Syria). However, it was decorated with massacres and protests and eventually the KMT lifted martial law in 1987.

Overall: mediocre, you could argue it but better pieces of evidence out there

What role did political leaders play in the changes in their country? (B)
The period of martial law serves as a way to show how CKS was extremely powerful and able to hold control over Taiwan
But, it's probably better to point to Mao and the CCP's ironclad control, much stronger
How did people contribute to political changes in their country? (C)
People were still willing to protest and riot, which triggered the 2/28 Incident
But still not really, martial law really doesn't show the people, just use the 2/28 Incident directly.
What led to economic success/failure in China and Taiwan? (F)
Really difficult to truly argue this point, maybe????

item.title: Graphing Exponentials
item.description:
#math #exponents
#math #exponents


Parent graph of all exponential functions of base is - there is no general parent graph! General note: make sure to factor your function into standard form and remove coefficients
Decay functions can be treated as horizontal reflections of the parent graph


Growth functions are of the form where and have an upwards curve
Decay functions are where and can be treated as horizontal reflections of
- Vertically reflected functions (e.g over x-axis) are NEITHER GROWTH NOR DECAY
is neither growth nor decay

Exponential Features

Everything is just flipped!
to graph inverses, just flip x and y for everything.

R: D:
Opposite of exponential graph

item.title: Inverse Functions
item.description:
#math
#math
Inverse functions are functions which reverse the process of a given function, basically changing x and y --> this basically allows you to get your inputs back from your outputs.
Inverse functions only exists for one to one functions! You must domain restrict a function if it's not one to one!

Represented as
Properties
The composition of the inverse and the normal function will always return the input --> if you get your inputs back from your outputs, it'll be the input again.
Mathematically
Domain and range flip when you invert
Graphically, acts like a reflection over the line

item.title: Logarithmic methods
item.description:
#math #logs #exponents
#math #logs #exponents
When U-sub is not able to be used and the bases are different, you can take the log of both sides in order to solve the equation.
When using this method, you can use ANY log
Example:

This is a general method but it should be your last resort. It only works when the base is isolated
Your goal is to try to reach clusters with log on one side and values on the other

item.title: Simplifying Exponentials
item.description:
#math #exponents
#math #exponents
In order to simplify an exponential

No negative exponents
All bases must be unique
No exponent should be raised to another exponent
We can achieve this via Exponential Properties.

item.title: Simplifying Logarithms
item.description:
#logs #math
#logs #math
You may be asked to condense or expand logarithms, and they have different rules to follow.

Log Condensing Rules
The coefficient must be 1
Rational exponents should be written in radical form
Leave the input in radical form
No need to rationalize!
Expanding Logs
No power, product, or quotient should remain in the input
Numerical logs should be in simplest terms.
Evaluate logs as much as possible ()
Use the Log Properties to simplify logs. Note that a lot of people mess these up, make sure to take extra care when using these!

An interesting problem on the last quiz involved an expression that simplified to

Now, you can actually simplify this further via change of base!

item.title: Solving Exponentials
item.description:
#math #exponents
#math #exponents
PLEASE PLEASE REMEMBER TO CHECK YOUR ANSWERS!
Methods

Exponential One to One
The most general method, anytime you have two exponentials to the same base you can set and solve from there.
Noncheckable
U-sub
Useful when you get a quadratic looking exponentials, usually of the form
Checkable
Logarithmic methods
- Useful when you can't solve cleanly into bases. You can use any log on an equation like to isolate x - and you can solve from there.
- Checkable-ish
Always check if you can use One to One, then U-sub, then logs to make it easier.
The goofy example here is where you can distribute the logs to isolate, which is something you definitely want to keep in mind
e.g

item.title: Solving Logs
item.description:
#logs #math
#logs #math
PLEASE PLEASE REMEMBER TO CHECK YOUR ANSWERS!

Logs One-to-One
Useful anytime you only have log expressions
Changing to Exponential
- Useful for everything else!
- Technically you can get here by doing Logs One-to-One by subtracting a 1-1 on both sides and simplifying... You only have two strategies: rewrite everything as two logs on both sides, or rewrite everything as the same base. Everything else won't solve cleanly.
Always see if you can easily Logs One-to-One first, as it's a little bit cleaner

item.title: Terminology
item.description:
#math #logs #exponents
#math #logs #exponents

The power is the entire expression (), and the exponent is only the value that determines how many times something is multiplied. () The base is the value that is being raised by an exponent ().


e, Euler's number is an irrational number that is the limit of a function
ln is the log with base e , called the natural log because of how often it appears in nature


Usually, logs without bases are and called the common log
But in computer science logs without bases are so don't take it for granted!


Solve
Leave answer as expression
Solve for a variable
Evaluate
results in an actual value
Simplify
Make cleaner or more compact
Pateledefinition: less operations
Logs: Condensing/Expanding
Exponential: Simplifying Exponentials


In the expression , is the growth factor, it determines how fast the exponential function grows
Used to determine if a function is growth or decay


In exponential functions, it's in which also turns out to be the y-intercept (because )

item.title: Test Strategy
item.description:
Some of these are guesses, which are italicized

Calculator
At least one using general formulas
Probably one that asks you to get the input back
One intersection
MCQs
Conceptual understanding
FRQs
Testing problem solving skills
Writing????
Graphing


Exponents
Expand to increase options then simplify
U-sub to help manage your variables
U-sub as soon as you see quadratic like stuff
Or just condense, as long as you try to reduce the problem to make it easier
reach a position where you can log, one-one, U-sub
- log -> get two clusters, one with all the powers, one with all the values and log the entire thing to isolate the exponents
- one-one -> get powers of the same base on both sides and then solve
- You can't do one-one if there are any elements that are not powers, always change everything to same base if you want to use this
- U-sub -> only use when you see multiple repeated powers, especially quadratic-like equations
- Useful for the simplifying step as well to make math cleaner For U-Sub, remember your equation for u is not the same as the initial variable you were solving for!!! And always check!!!
Logs
You only have two strategies: rewrite everything as two logs on both sides, or rewrite everything as the same base.
Logs One-to-One
Rewriting as Exponential
PLEASE PLEASE CHECK LOGS, YOU ALSO NEED TO CHECK FOR U-SUB


Why hard?
You gonna forget that you can't do your log rules on negative logs
No solution/Undefined
What is the inverse function of ?
Why hard?
Forgetting to range restrict

or


Find all integer solutions for x,m

Why hard?
Too many ways to try to approach this at the start, approach it by trying to simplify as much as possible
Recommendation: Expand first, then condense!


Find the loudness of a noise that has 15 kW per square kilometer
Why hard?
You forget to convert the units to what the inputs were supposed to be...


Transformations
Always factor out the coefficients of
Focus on the key point

- Subtraction/addition
- Terms

- Actual values in sequence
- Constant
- Never changes
- Ratio
- Multiplication/Division

item.title: Quick Note
item.description:
#math #sequencies #series
Tags: #math #sequencies #series
Date: 2025-05-06

Sequences
Anything that has a pattern
Formally, a number sequence is a ordered list of numbers defined by a rule. ==
==The numbers of the sequence are called the terms
The domain must be the set of positive numbers.
List of terms with a pattern NOTE THAT 0 IS NOT INCLUDED
N MUST START AT N=1
Recognize
Sequences may only be evaluated at natural numbers
Discrete points, not continuous curve
Look for alternating signs
Look for terms increasing/decreasing by common difference
Look for common ratio
Look for relationships via table of values
Linear
Quadratic
Cubic
Exponential

item.title: Terminology
item.description:
Sequence
Formally, a number sequence is a ordered list of numbers defined by a rule.
The numbers of the sequence are called the terms
Basically a list of terms with a pattern
The domain must be the set of positive natural numbers. NOTE THAT 0 IS NOT INCLUDED
N MUST START AT N=1
Finite
Fixed amount
Show end either with or just
"Finite" could end on the general term, which is still infinite
Infinite
Use ellipses that continue to nothing
No end, sequence evaluates for all natural numbers
Bracket Notation

is the whole sequence when there is bracket notation
Make sure to have nth term at the end
General Term
Without brackets is the term for any term

item.title: Angle of Incidence
item.description:
The angle of a ray compared with the normal (perpendicular) of any mirror line
Note that it's compared to the normal, not the surface!

item.title: Angle of Reflection
item.description:
The angle of a reflected ray compared with the normal (perpendicular) of any mirror line.
Note that it's compared to the normal, not the surface!

item.title: Concave
item.description:
The focus is at half of the radius of the concave mirror
Center of curvature is twice the focus distance, where the object looks the same size.
The orientation is flipped until the object passes the focal point,
but the image changes to a virtual image.
Magnification is always smaller until you get closer to the focus, and because the center

Given the Mirror Equations we can show that the magnification is greater than 1.

item.title: Convex
item.description:
The focus is at half of the radius of the convex mirror
Magnification is always less than one, so you always appear smaller
The focus is always behind the mirror
Always creates a virtual image
Image is always upright (virtual image)

item.title: Initial note
item.description:
#physics
Tags: #physics
Date: 2025-05-06

When mirror becomes a projector as reaches infinity
Mag becomes infinite

item.title: Law of Reflection
item.description:
The Angle of Incidence is equal to the Angle of Reflection of any incident ray.

After reflection, the ray is called the reflected ray, and the source of the image seen (the Virtual Image) seems to come from within the mirror.
Furthermore, because of this , the image distance and the viewing distance is the same

See Lab 8-1 for the experiment to determine it

item.title: Mirror Equations
item.description:
Focus of mirror

Magnification equation

negative means that the image is inverted
Mirror equation

item.title: PHYSICS
item.description:
Law of Reflection
Principal Focus
Mirror Equations
Ray Diagram

item.title: Principal Focus
item.description:
In a Concave mirror, there is a principal focus where all of the rays converge outside of the mirror
In a Convex mirror, the light reflects as if there is a focus within the mirror
The principal focus is where all light rays must cross, which could mean that the rays intersect and enter the focus or the place where the rays seem to come from

in a convex mirror, after the light reflects and the virtual image is always in the same place

item.title: Ray Diagram
item.description:
Two rays emanating from a single point on the image
Flat
Draw one perpendicular and another that reflects off, then draw their intersection for virtual image.
Concave & Convex
==If the ray is parallel to the principal axis, it will reflect and go through the focus
==If the ray is going through the focus, it will reflect and be parallel to the principal axis
Concave is caved in
One ray parallel to the principal axis which will reflect through the focus
One ray through the object and principal focus which will reflect and create a ray parallel to the principal axis
In the case of the object being closer than the focus, draw from the focus to the object
3 main cases
Object is behind focus
Object is between focus and center of curvature
Object is in front of focus
Convex is facing outwards (i.e not caved in)
One ray parallel to the principal axis that reflects off and seems to intersect the focus

item.title: Virtual Image
item.description:
This happens when the reflected rays diverge thus making it impossible to project onto a screen
A real image is able to be projected as light rays still intersect in front of the mirror
The image of the object inside the mirror
The reflected rays act like they are receiving light rays from the virtual image itself
By viewing the virtual image, everything is identical compared to looking at the object from the same distance
Because Law of Reflection
